0.52.text:
Major internet service providers, or ISP’s,
like AT&T, Comcast, and Verizon would like

6.12.text:
nothing more than end Net Neutrality. Instead
of being mired down in explaining how net

11.29.text:
neutrality works, let’s talk about the consequences
of losing it. Will the death of Net Neutrality

17.52.text:
In its simple terms, yes. It could restrict
the sites you’re able to access AND take

23.15.text:
your money. And THAT is why ISP’s wanna
get rid of Net Neutrality. They want more

27.74.text:
control over the web. And they want to get
more money out of their internet service business.

29.71.text:
They want a world where people and companies
pay based on the amount, the quality, and

33.84.text: the type of internet they use.

35.91.text:
They’re arguing that ending net neutrality
could avoid potential traffic jams and congestion

40.53.text:
within the system. That companies like Netflix
and Google offer services that eat up more

45.26.text:
bandwidth than your average blog or retail
website. So why shouldn’t Netflix, or Google,

50.45.text:
pay extra to ensure that the ISPs can handle
the extreme amount of bandwidth?

53.76.text:
Sounds like a decent argument. Watching a
movie on Netflix does take more bandwidth

55.83.text:
than reading an article on a text only site.
So what’s the problem with admitting that,

56.80.text: and making Netflix pay a little more?

57.20.text:
Well, Netflix isn’t a non-profit organization;
they have to make money. If they have to pay

59.65.text:
more, you have to pay more for their service.
And it won’t stop with Netflix. Google,

64.43.text:
facebook, Yahoo… all of these company’s
services eat up a lot of bandwidth and they’d

70.77.text:
Which means more ads, more pay sites, and
less money spent on new initiatives and free

75.44.text:
services like mapping programs, document storage,
or search engines. It also means that start-up

77.88.text:
costs for new websites could go up, giving
us less to choose from and hampering innovation.

82.37.text:
Plus, the ISP’s don’t have to stop there.
If they can charge Netflix a premium rate,

87.22.text:
why can’t they charge you a premium rate
for accessing premium sites?

91.35.text:
They could have a basic package that gives
you email, IM, and retail sites for only $10.99

96.05.text:
a month. Maybe a premium plan that allows
facebook and twitter for $29.99. Or a Premium

101.89.text:
Plus plan with Netflix and HD streaming for
only $79.99. And for the super rich, a Premium

108.00.text:
Plus Unlimited Gold plan that offers the entire
internet the way it was before they killed

112.74.text:
net neutrality - for only $149.99 a month.
And they’ll throw in a landline for free,

118.13.text:
because after seeing what the death of net
neutrality will do to your mobile plan - you’ll

122.67.text:
There are a bunch of other reasons to save
net neutrality, but if you only need one - safeguarding

128.31.text:
Americans against price jacking from companies
that love price jacking is a pretty good one.

133.32.text:
Go to fcc.gov/comments to let the FCC know
what you think about this issue and if you
